intro: Salix barclayi var. neomexicana, commonly known as the New Mexico willow, is a shrub or small tree native to the southwestern United States. It typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, such as rocky soils and stream banks. The plant has slender, zigzagging branches and produces catkins in early spring. Its leaves are lance-shaped, often with a rough texture and a bluish-green color. It is well adapted to drought conditions and plays a role in stabilizing soil in its native habitat.
